div.head:
Embleme 34. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Hee is conceived in baths, and borne in the aire, and being made
red walks upon the waters.

div.head: Discourse 34.
div.ab:
The opinion or flattery of men attributes wonderfull births to some-
persons above others, but certainly fabulous, as to Alexander the great,
begotten not by Philip King of Macedonia, but Jupiter Hammon; to-
Romulus and Remus, by Mars; to Plato, borne of the virgin Perictione
violated by the image of Apollo: soeso></choice the Heathen would demonstrate
themselves to proceed from the Gods, as allso Thessulus the Sonne of Hippo
crates the Physician doth amongst other things endeavour to perswadepersuade-
himselfe to descend from Apollo at Athens: but wee cannot easily beleive
them, who know, that they were neither men nor Gods, to whome they
referrerefer the originall of their lineage: And if the Heroes were amongst
men as divine, wee conceive all those magnificent actions boasted in-
the world, through the adulation of Subjects, disciples, or others, were things
faignedfeigned of them, and insinuated into the opinion of the vulgar by-
forged writings: The thing is different, that the Philosophers ascribe an unusu
allunsual conception and nativity to their Sonne; for hee hath something peculiar-
above all other things borne in the world, hee being conceivd in baths, and
borne in the aire. Wee know that women being barren through overmuch
coldnesse and siccity may be much helped by hott baths, soeso></choice as to be made
able and fitt for conception, but that it should be done in baths is a thing
unheard of: that seems to appertaine to him alone, by reason of the won
derfull power of nature farre different from other things. they elswhere say,
that hee must be conceivd in the bottome of the vessell, and borne in the-
Alembicke: which opinion is more conspicuous: For the waters of baths, if-
there be any, will not be at the top, nor in the midle, but in the bottome of
the vessell, and in the Alembicke are airy vapours: where therefore con
ception is made, hee ascends into the Alembicke, and his birth appears in a
white colour: Blacknesse rules in the bottome, concerning which sayth the
Rosary; Conception is, when the earth is dissolved into a blacke pouderpowder, and
begins to retaineretain somewhat of the Mercury; for then the male acts upon
the female, that is, Azoth upon the earth. And a little after: Conception-
and desponsation is made in putrefaction in the bottome of the vessell,
and the generation of things generated will be made in the aire, to witt,
in the head of the vessell, that is, the Alembicke: And conception in
baths is nothing els but putrefaction in dung: for soeso></choice the same Rosary
continuethcontinues: The body dos nothing, unlesse it be putrefyd, and it cannot
be putrefyd, except with Mercury: And soone after: Putrefaction must
be effected with a most gentle heat of warme and moist dung, and by
noe other thing, soeso></choice that nothing ascend, because if any thing should
ascend, there would be a separation of the parts, which ought not to be,
till the male and female be perfectly joynd together, and one re
ceive the other, the signe of which perfect solution is blacknesse in-
the superficies. His birth is white, which is consummated at the top
Discourse 34.
of mountains, that is, in the aire or Alembicke; which is by Rosinus to
Euthicia thus explained: The wise man sayd. Take things out of their
Mynes, and exalt them to higher places, and send them from the top
of their mountains, and reduce them to their roots: And afterwards: But
by mountains hee signifydsignified Cucurbits, and by the tops of mountains
Alembicks: and to send is according to similitude to receive the water
of them by an Alembicke in a Receiver: and to reduce to the roots, is to
that, from which they proceed: and hee named Cucurbits mountains,
because Sol and Luna are found in mountains: soeso></choice allso in the moun
tains, which are Cucurbits, are their Sol and Luna generated: These
are his words: Afterwards hee becomes red, and begins to goe upon the
waters, that is, upon metalls melted by fire, which stand in the forme
of a mercuriall water: For hee is the lord of waters, upon which
hee exercisethexercises authority, as Neptune, and is the king of the Sea,
and the possessor of mountains. Of Xerxes King of Persia they-
report, that being upon an expedition into Greece, hee sent an-
embassy to the Sea, and to the mountaine Athos, that they would
doe him noe wrong, that by the force of waves, this of fire, other
wise that hee would take revenge upon them both: But the tale-
was told to them that were deafedeaf, and the Sea drowned some of his
ships, and Athos destroyd not a few by fire. Hereupon the King be
ing angry, did, as lord fo the Sea and mountains, comand a cer
taine number of stripes to be inflicted upon the first, and a great
part of the mountaine hee cast into the sea: but these things doe
demonstrate the rashnesserashness rather than the prudence of soeso></choice great a
king: Hee, of whome wee speake, purgethpurges all waters from obstacles;-
and impurityesimpurities, not by edict, but fact, and freely passethpasses through them,
which allso (which is more) hee congealethcongeals, soeso></choice as by their hardnesse to
bear his chariots, in which ships sayldsailed before: Hee makes mountains
æquall with vallyes, and fears not the flames of fire, and therefore
goes freely wheresoever hee please, from the pillars of Hercules in
the farthest parts of India, to the pillars of Dionysius. . . .
